message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change of combustion (ΔH°c) for propane (C3H8) gas at 298 K, given the balanced chemical equation: C3H8(g) + 5O2(g) -> 3CO2(g) + 4H2O(g)?
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change of combustion (ΔH°c) for propane (C3H8) gas at 298 K, we need the standard enthalpies of formation (ΔH°f) for the reactants and products involved in the balanced chemical equation.

The balanced chemical equation is:
C3H8(g) + 5O2(g) -> 3CO2(g) + 4H2O(g)

The standard enthalpies of formation (ΔH°f) for the substances involved are:
ΔH°f [C3H8(g)] = -103.85 kJ/mol
ΔH°f [O2(g)] = 0 kJ/mol (since O2 is in its standard state)
ΔH°f [CO2(g)] = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔH°f [H2O(g)] = -241.8 kJ/mol

Now, we can calculate the standard enthalpy change of combustion (ΔH°c) using the following equation:
ΔH°c = Σ [ΔH°f (products)] - Σ [ΔH°f (reactants)]

ΔH°c = [3 × (-393.5 kJ/mol) + 4 × (-241.8 kJ/mol)] - [(-103.85 kJ/mol) + 5 × 0 kJ/mol]

ΔH°c = (-1180.5 kJ/mol + (-967.2 kJ/mol)) - (-103.85 kJ/mol)

ΔH°c = -2147.7 kJ/mol + 103.85 kJ/mol

ΔH°c = -2043.85 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy change of combustion (ΔH°c) for propane (C3H8) gas at 298 K is approximately -2043.85 kJ/mol.
